hints: A substance that cannot be broken down by chemical means.
Defined by its number of protons.
Examples include oxygen and gold.
A substance formed from two or more elements.
Held together by chemical bonds.
Water is a classic example.
The basic unit of a chemical element.
Consists of a nucleus and electrons.
Democritus and Dalton contributed to its theory.
A group of two or more atoms bonded together.
The smallest particle of a compound.
Can be a single element like $O_2$ or a compound like $H_2O$.
An atom or molecule with an electrical charge.
Can be a cation or an anion.
Formed by losing or gaining electrons.
A subatomic particle with a positive charge.
Found in the nucleus of an atom.
Its number defines the element.
A subatomic particle with no charge.
Found in the nucleus of an atom.
Along with protons, determines the atomic mass.
A subatomic particle with a negative charge.
Orbits the nucleus of an atom.
Involved in chemical bonding.
The dense center of an atom.
Contains protons and neutrons.
Discovered by Rutherford.
The force that holds atoms together.
Can be ionic or covalent.
The attraction between atoms.
The outermost shell of electrons in an atom.
Electrons in this shell are involved in bonding.
Determines an element's reactivity.
Atoms of the same element with a different number of neutrons.
Have the same atomic number but different mass numbers.
Carbon-12 and Carbon-14 are examples.
A chart of all known elements.
Organized by atomic number, electron configuration, and chemical properties.
Its modern form was largely created by Mendeleev.
A substance that donates a proton or accepts an electron pair.
Has a pH less than 7.
Tastes sour and can corrode metals.
A substance that accepts a proton or donates an electron pair.
Has a pH greater than 7.
Tastes bitter and feels slippery.
A measure of how acidic or basic a substance is.
A scale from 0 to 14.
7 is considered neutral.
An ionic compound formed from a reaction between an acid and a base.
Sodium chloride is the most common example.
Found on a kitchen table.
The process of a chemical change.
Reactants are converted into products.
A transformation of substances.
A substance that speeds up a chemical reaction.
It is not consumed in the reaction.
Enzymes are an example in biology.
A state in which forward and reverse reaction rates are equal.
The concentrations of reactants and products remain constant.
A state of balance.
The calculation of quantities in chemical reactions.
Based on the law of conservation of mass.
Helps predict the amount of product formed.
A method to determine the concentration of a substance.
Involves adding a solution of known concentration to one of unknown concentration.
Often uses an indicator to detect the endpoint.
The creation of a new compound from simpler substances.
Often involves a combination reaction.
A type of chemical reaction.
The loss of electrons.
Often involves gaining oxygen.
Part of a redox reaction.
The gain of electrons.
Often involves losing oxygen.
Part of a redox reaction.
A chemical compound that contains at least one oxygen atom.
Can be a metal or non-metal.
Rust is an example.
A large molecule made of repeating subunits.
Plastics are a common example.
Can be natural or synthetic.
A single repeating subunit of a polymer.
Amino acids are a type of this.
The building block of a larger molecule.
The process of speeding up a chemical reaction.
Performed by a catalyst.
Lowers the activation energy.
A homogeneous mixture of two or more substances.
Consists of a solute and a solvent.
Salt dissolved in water is an example.
The substance being dissolved in a solution.
The minority component.
The salt in saltwater.
The substance doing the dissolving in a solution.
The majority component.
The water in saltwater.
The measure of how much solute is in a solution.
Can be expressed as molarity or percent.
The strength of a solution.
A measure of concentration.
Moles of solute per liter of solution.
Represented by the symbol M.
A unit of measurement for a large number of particles.
Equal to $6.022 	imes 10^{23}$ particles.
Known as Avogadro's number.
An Italian scientist.
His number is $6.022 	imes 10^{23}$.
Related to the mole concept.
The simplest whole-number ratio of atoms in a compound.
Benzene's is $CH$.
Contrasts with the molecular formula.
The actual number of atoms of each element in a molecule.
Benzene's is $C_6H_6$.
Can be a multiple of the empirical formula.
A chemical reaction that involves burning a substance.
Reactants are a fuel and an oxidant, usually oxygen.
Produces heat and light.
Mass per unit of volume.
A physical property of a substance.
Tells you how compact a substance is.
A measure of a fluid's resistance to flow.
Honey has a high one.
A physical property.
The phase change from solid directly to gas.
Dry ice is a common example.
Does not pass through a liquid phase.
The phase change from gas to liquid.
Water vapor turning into liquid water.
Often seen on a cold glass.
The phase change from liquid to gas.
Occurs at the surface of a liquid.
How puddles disappear.
The phase change from solid to liquid.
Occurs when a substance is heated to its melting point.
Ice turning into water.
The phase change from liquid to solid.
Occurs when a substance is cooled to its freezing point.
Water turning into ice.
A type of mixture that is uniform throughout.
Its components are not visually distinct.
Saltwater is an example.
A type of mixture that is not uniform throughout.
Its components are visually distinct.
Oil and water is an example.
A heterogeneous mixture.
Particles are large enough to settle out over time.
Muddy water is an example.
A type of mixture with particles larger than a solution.
Particles are too small to settle out.
Milk and fog are examples.
The study of chemical processes within living organisms.
Combines biology and chemistry.
Focuses on molecules like proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates.
The study of compounds containing carbon.
Often involves hydrocarbons.
The chemistry of life.
The study of all elements and compounds except for organic ones.
Includes minerals, metals, and salts.
Opposite of organic chemistry.
The study of separating, identifying, and quantifying chemical substances.
Helps determine what a substance is made of.
Involves techniques like chromatography and spectroscopy.
The study of the physical principles behind chemical systems.
Combines physics and chemistry.
Involves topics like thermodynamics and kinetics.
An organic compound containing only hydrogen and carbon atoms.
The primary components of petroleum.
Methane is the simplest example.
A saturated hydrocarbon.
Contains only single carbon-carbon bonds.
Methane and ethane are examples.
An unsaturated hydrocarbon.
Contains at least one carbon-carbon double bond.
Ethene is the simplest example.
An unsaturated hydrocarbon.
Contains at least one carbon-carbon triple bond.
Ethyne is the simplest example.
Molecules with the same formula but different structures.
Example butane and isobutane.
They have different physical and chemical properties.
A functional group.
Often have a fruity or sweet smell.
Used in perfumes and flavorings.
A functional group.
A derivative of ammonia.
Found in many biologically active compounds.
An organic compound containing a hydroxyl group.
Methanol and ethanol are examples.
Used in beverages and as a solvent.
A biomolecule made of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen.
A primary source of energy.
Sugars and starches are examples.
A large biomolecule made of amino acid chains.
Perform a wide variety of functions in organisms.
Meat and eggs are good sources.
A biomolecule that is soluble in organic solvents but not water.
Includes fats, oils, and waxes.
Used for energy storage and cell membranes.
A nucleic acid that contains genetic instructions.
Forms a double helix structure.
Passed from parent to offspring.
A biological catalyst.
Usually a protein.
Speeds up biochemical reactions.
A French nobleman and chemist.
Considered the 'father of modern chemistry'.
Helped create the metric system.
An English chemist and physicist.
Pioneered modern atomic theory.
Also studied color blindness.
A Russian chemist.
Created the periodic table of elements.
Organized elements based on their properties.
A Polish and naturalized French physicist and chemist.
Pioneered research on radioactivity.
The first woman to win a Nobel Prize.
A simple laboratory container.
Used for mixing and heating chemicals.
Has a flat bottom and a lip for pouring.
A type of laboratory flask.
Has a flat bottom and a conical body.
Used for titrations and heating liquids.
A piece of laboratory glassware.
Used to dispense a precise volume of liquid.
A long, graduated tube with a stopcock.
A laboratory tool.
Used to measure and transfer a small volume of liquid.
A small glass tube with a bulb or plunger.
An instrument used to measure the intensity of light.
Helps identify unknown substances.
Can analyze the spectrum of light.
A substance used in a chemical reaction.
Often added to a system to cause a reaction.
The chemicals in a lab.
A solid that forms from a solution during a reaction.
Falls out of the solution.
Can be seen as a cloudy substance.
The process of forming a solid from a solution.
A type of chemical reaction.
The reverse of dissolving.
A substance that can act as both an acid and a base.
Water is the most common example.
Can donate or accept a proton.
A solution that resists changes in pH.
Maintains a stable pH level.
Often a mixture of a weak acid and its conjugate base.
A substance that produces an electrically conducting solution.
Formed when dissolved in a polar solvent like water.
Gatorade contains these.
The electrode where oxidation occurs.
Has a positive charge in an electrolytic cell.
Where electrons are lost.
The electrode where reduction occurs.
Has a negative charge in an electrolytic cell.
Where electrons are gained.
The minimum energy required for a chemical reaction to occur.
The 'hill' that reactants must climb.
Catalysts lower this.
The study of heat, work, and energy.
Relates to spontaneity of reactions.
Includes concepts like entropy and enthalpy.
A measure of disorder or randomness in a system.
The universe tends toward greater disorder.
A thermodynamic property.
A measure of the total heat content of a system.
Can be positive (endothermic) or negative (exothermic).
A chemical reaction that releases energy as heat.
Feels hot to the touch.
The enthalpy change is negative.
A chemical reaction that absorbs energy as heat.
Feels cold to the touch.
The enthalpy change is positive.
The study of the rate of chemical reactions.
Deals with how fast a reaction occurs.
Factors include temperature and concentration.
A type of reaction involving both oxidation and reduction.
Electrons are transferred between species.
A shortened term.
To change directly from a solid to a gas.
Dry ice does this at room temperature.
The process is called sublimation.
The process of separating a solid from a liquid.
Uses a porous material like paper.
Used to separate a precipitate from a solution.
The process of separating a liquid mixture.
Uses selective boiling and condensation.
Used to purify water or alcohol.
A method for separating mixtures.
Separates components based on their properties.
Often used to separate pigments.
The study of the interaction between matter and electromagnetic radiation.
Used to analyze chemical substances.
Helps identify unknown compounds.
An analytical technique.
Measures the mass-to-charge ratio of ions.
Used to determine the composition of a sample.
A discrete packet of energy or matter.
The smallest possible unit of something.
Relates to how electrons are arranged.
A mathematical function describing the wave-like behavior of an electron.
A region of space where an electron is likely to be found.
S, P, D, and F are the four main types.
The arrangement of electrons in an atom.
Follows rules like the Aufbau principle.
Describes how electrons fill orbitals.
A type of chemical bond.
Involves the sharing of electrons.
Forms molecules.
A type of chemical bond.
Involves the transfer of electrons.
Forms ions and ionic compounds.
A type of chemical bond.
Found in metals.
A sea of delocalized electrons.
Different structural forms of the same element.
Carbon's forms include diamond and graphite.
Phosphorus has red and white versions.
A solid material whose constituents are arranged in a highly ordered structure.
Salt and sugar are examples.
Often has a distinctive shape.
A solid that lacks a long-range ordered structure.
Glass is a common example.
Opposite of a crystal.
To change from a solid to a gas without becoming a liquid.
This is a verb form of the phase change.
Dry ice can do this.
The study of heat changes in chemical reactions.
A branch of physical chemistry.
Includes concepts like enthalpy and heat of formation.
A device used to measure heat flow.
Used to determine the enthalpy of a reaction.
A coffee cup can be a simple version.
A measure of disorder or randomness in a system.
The universe tends toward greater disorder.
A thermodynamic property.
A group of highly reactive nonmetals.
Includes fluorine, chlorine, bromine, iodine, and astatine.
Group 17 on the periodic table.
A group of highly reactive metals.
Includes lithium, sodium, and potassium.
Group 1 on the periodic table.
A group of unreactive, inert gases.
Includes helium, neon, and argon.
Group 18 on the periodic table.
A large group of metals.
Includes iron, copper, and gold.
The d-block of the periodic table.
A series of rare-earth metals.
Elements 57 to 71 on the periodic table.
Named after the element Lanthanum.
A series of radioactive metals.
Elements 89 to 103 on the periodic table.
Named after the element Actinium.
A substance formed from two or more elements.
Held together by chemical bonds.
Water is a classic example.
A measure of the concentration of hydrogen ions.
The pH scale measures this.
The quality of being an acid.
A measure of the concentration of hydroxide ions.
The opposite of acidity.
The quality of being a base.
A reaction between an acid and a base.
Forms a salt and water.
The pH of the resulting solution is 7.
A substance that changes color in response to pH.
Phenolphthalein is a common one.
Used in titrations to find the endpoint.
The point in a titration where the indicator changes color.
Marks the completion of the reaction.
Not to be confused with the equivalence point.
The point in a titration where the moles of acid equal the moles of base.
The theoretical point of neutralization.
Ideal state of a reaction.
A substance that causes oxidation in another substance.
It gets reduced in the process.
Accepts electrons.
A substance that causes reduction in another substance.
It gets oxidized in the process.
Donates electrons.
The decomposition of a substance by an electric current.
Used to extract metals from their ores.
Splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen.
An electrochemical cell that generates electrical energy from a spontaneous reaction.
A battery is a common example.
Also known as a voltaic cell.
An electrochemical cell that uses electrical energy to drive a non-spontaneous reaction.
Requires an external power source.
Used in electroplating.
The process of coating an object with a thin layer of metal.
Uses an electrolytic cell.
Used to make jewelry.
A horizontal row on the periodic table.
Elements in the same one have the same number of electron shells.
There are 7 of them.
A vertical column on the periodic table.
Elements in the same one have similar chemical properties.
There are 18 of them.
An element with properties between a metal and a nonmetal.
Found on the 'staircase' of the periodic table.
Boron, silicon, and germanium are examples.
An element that is a poor conductor of heat and electricity.
Often found as gases or brittle solids.
Oxygen, carbon, and sulfur are examples.
An element that is a good conductor of heat and electricity.
Often shiny and malleable.
Iron, copper, and gold are examples.
The mixing of atomic orbitals to form new hybrid orbitals.
Explains the geometry of molecules.
$sp^3, sp^2, and sp$ are types.
A model used to predict the geometry of molecules.
Based on the repulsion of electron pairs.
An acronym for Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion.
A separation of electric charge in a molecule.
Leads to a dipole moment.
Water is a highly example of this.
The tendency of liquid surfaces to shrink into the minimum surface area.
Caused by the cohesion of liquid molecules.
Allows insects to walk on water.
A measure of a fluid's resistance to flow.
Honey has a high one.
A physical property.
The pressure exerted by a vapor in thermodynamic equilibrium with its condensed phases.
The pressure above a liquid.
Water has a higher one than honey at room temperature.
The temperature at which a liquid changes to a gas.
Where vapor pressure equals atmospheric pressure.
100 degrees Celsius for water at sea level.
The temperature at which a liquid changes to a solid.
0 degrees Celsius for water at sea level.
The opposite of melting point.
The ability of a substance to dissolve in a solvent.
Sugar has a high one in water.
Relates to 'like dissolves like'.
Two liquids that can be mixed in any ratio to form a homogeneous solution.
Water and alcohol are examples.
Opposite of immiscible.
Two liquids that cannot be mixed to form a homogeneous solution.
Oil and water are examples.
Opposite of miscible.
A solution containing the maximum amount of dissolved solute.
No more solute can be dissolved.
A solution that cannot take any more solute.
A solution containing less than the maximum amount of dissolved solute.
More solute can be dissolved.
A solution that can take more solute.
A solution containing more than the maximum amount of dissolved solute.
An unstable state.
Heating a solution can create this.
The common name for ethyne.
A flammable gas.
Used in welding torches.
A chemical compound with the formula $NH_3$.
A colorless gas with a pungent smell.
Used in fertilizers and cleaning products.
An organic chemical compound with the formula $C_6H_6$.
A ring structure of six carbon atoms.
A highly flammable, toxic liquid.
The simplest alcohol.
Highly toxic.
Also known as wood alcohol.
The alcohol found in alcoholic beverages.
Also used as a fuel.
Made by fermenting sugar.
The chemical name for table sugar.
A disaccharide.
Made of glucose and fructose.
A simple sugar.
The main source of energy for living organisms.
The product of photosynthesis.
A simple sugar.
Found in many fruits.
Sweeter than glucose.
A sugar found in milk.
A disaccharide.
People who are intolerant to this cannot digest it.
A complex carbohydrate.
The main component of plant cell walls.
What wood and paper are mostly made of.
A complex carbohydrate.
Used by plants for energy storage.
Found in potatoes, rice, and wheat.
A complex carbohydrate.
The main component of the exoskeletons of insects and crustaceans.
Also found in the cell walls of fungi.
The process of converting atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia.
Done by certain bacteria.
Essential for plant growth.
A process for synthesizing ammonia.
Revolutionized agriculture.
Named after two German chemists.
The study of chemical reactions initiated by light.
Photosynthesis is a type of this.
A sub-discipline of chemistry.
The study of the relationship between electricity and chemical reactions.
Involves topics like batteries and electrolysis.
A sub-discipline of chemistry.
The manipulation of matter on an atomic and molecular scale.
Creating materials at a tiny size.
A modern field of science.
A process of reacting monomers to form a polymer.
The creation of a large molecule from smaller ones.
How plastics are made.
The ability of an element to form chains with itself.
Carbon is the best example.
A key property of organic chemistry.
A type of covalent bond where both electrons come from one atom.
A dative bond.
Found in complex ions.
The study of matter and its properties.
How matter is transformed.
The central science.
The calculation of quantities in chemical reactions.
Based on the law of conservation of mass.
Helps predict the amount of product formed.
A measure of concentration.
Moles of solute per kilogram of solvent.
Represented by a lowercase m.
The ratio of moles of one component to the total moles of all components.
Used to express concentration.
Unitless.
The process of reducing the concentration of a solution.
Adding more solvent to a solution.
Makes a solution less strong.
The process of forming a solid crystal from a solution.
A purification technique.
The reverse of dissolving.
A substance that has undergone sublimation.
Dry ice vapor is an example.
A gas formed directly from a solid.
The phase change from gas directly to solid.
Frost forming is an example.
The opposite of sublimation.
The phase change from solid to liquid.
Also known as melting.
A term used in nuclear chemistry.
The phase change from liquid to gas.
Includes boiling and evaporation.
A general term.
A graph showing the states of a substance under different pressures and temperatures.
Shows the triple point and critical point.
Maps out the different phases.
The unique temperature and pressure at which all three phases of a substance coexist.
Solid, liquid, and gas are in equilibrium.
A specific point on a phase diagram.
The end of a phase equilibrium curve.
The temperature and pressure at which a substance becomes a supercritical fluid.
The point beyond which liquid and gas are indistinguishable.
A property of solutions that depends on the number of solute particles.
Examples include boiling point elevation and freezing point depression.
Does not depend on the type of solute.
The net movement of a solvent through a semipermeable membrane.
Moves from a region of low solute concentration to high.
A type of diffusion.
The breaking of a bond by the addition of water.
A decomposition reaction.
Water is a reactant.
A chemical reaction that forms a polymer by removing a water molecule.
The opposite of hydrolysis.
Also known as condensation reaction.
A short chain of amino acids.
Forms a peptide bond.
A smaller version of a protein.
The process by which a protein assumes its functional three-dimensional shape.
Essential for its function.
Mistakes can lead to diseases like Alzheimer's.
The loss of a protein's three-dimensional structure.
Can be caused by heat or extreme pH.
An egg white turning solid when cooked is an example.
The region on an enzyme where a substrate binds.
The location of the catalytic action.
A specific shape for a specific molecule.
The molecule that an enzyme acts upon.
Binds to the active site.
The reactant in an enzyme-catalyzed reaction.
The first step of cellular respiration.
Breaks down glucose into pyruvate.
Occurs in the cytoplasm.
An anaerobic process that produces energy.
Used by yeast to make alcohol.
Occurs in the absence of oxygen.
Two molecules that are mirror images of each other.
They are non-superimposable.
A type of stereoisomer.
A property of asymmetry in a molecule.
Molecules that have this property are non-superimposable on their mirror image.
Related to the word for 'hand'.
Molecules with the same formula and connectivity but a different arrangement of atoms in space.
Includes enantiomers and diastereomers.
A type of isomer.
The monomer of nucleic acids.
Made of a sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base.
The building block of DNA and RNA.
A biomolecule that carries genetic information.
DNA and RNA are examples.
A polymer of nucleotides.
An enzyme that breaks down lipids.
Essential for fat digestion.
Found in the pancreas.

Turns liquid oils into solid fats.
Makes margarine.
A chemical reaction that adds water to a compound.
The opposite of dehydration.
Water is a reactant.
The process of converting a molecule into one of its isomers.
A type of chemical reaction.
Changing the structure of a molecule without changing the formula.
The decomposition of a substance by heat.
Used in industrial processes.
A thermal decomposition.

Reactants are a fuel and an oxidant, usually oxygen.
Produces heat and light.
The breaking of a bond by the addition of water.
A decomposition reaction.
Water is a reactant.
The decomposition of a substance by heat.
A type of chemical reaction.
Pyrolysis is a form of this.

Requires sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide.
Produces glucose and oxygen.
The process by which organisms convert glucose into energy.
Releases carbon dioxide and water.
The opposite of photosynthesis.
The 'powerhouse' of the cell.
Where cellular respiration occurs.
A double-membraned organelle.
The site of photosynthesis in plants.
Contains the pigment chlorophyll.
A double-membraned organelle.
The green pigment found in plants.
Absorbs light energy for photosynthesis.
Gives leaves their color.
A pigment that produces yellow, orange, and red colors.
Found in carrots and autumn leaves.
Aids in photosynthesis.
A state of matter.
Solid, liquid, and gas are examples.
Can be changed by temperature and pressure.
A state of matter.
Molecules are far apart and move randomly.
Has no fixed shape or volume.
A state of matter.
Molecules are close together but can move past each other.
Has a fixed volume but no fixed shape.
A state of matter.
Molecules are tightly packed and vibrate in place.
Has a fixed shape and volume.
A state of matter.
An ionized gas.
The most common state of matter in the universe.

Involves the transfer of electrons.
Forms ions and ionic compounds.
A type of chemical bond.
Involves the sharing of electrons.
Forms molecules.

Electrons are shared unequally.
Water is an example of this molecule.
A type of covalent bond.
Electrons are shared equally.
Methane is an example of this molecule.
A weak intermolecular force.
Forms between a hydrogen atom and an electronegative atom.
Responsible for water's unique properties.
A separation of positive and negative charges in a molecule.
Results in a polar molecule.
Has a 'dipole moment'.
The delocalization of electrons within a molecule.
Represented by multiple Lewis structures.
Benzene is a classic example.
The mixing of atomic orbitals to form new hybrid orbitals.
Explains the geometry of molecules.
$sp^3, sp^2, and sp$ are types.
A model used to predict the geometry of molecules.
Based on the repulsion of electron pairs.
An acronym for Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion.
The study of the three-dimensional arrangement of atoms in molecules.
Includes topics like chirality and stereoisomers.
A branch of chemistry.
A property of asymmetry in a molecule.
Molecules that have this property are non-superimposable on their mirror image.
Related to the word for 'hand'.
Two molecules that are mirror images of each other.
They are non-superimposable.
A type of stereoisomer.
Stereoisomers that are not mirror images of each other.
They have different physical properties.
A type of stereoisomer.
The step-by-step sequence of elementary reactions.
Describes how a reaction occurs.
A theoretical model of a reaction.
A substance that is formed during a reaction but is consumed in a later step.
Not a final product.
Often highly reactive.
A high-energy, unstable state that occurs during a reaction.
The peak of the energy hill.
Cannot be isolated.
An equation that relates reaction rate to the concentration of reactants.
Determined experimentally.
A component of chemical kinetics.
The power to which a reactant's concentration is raised in the rate law.
Can be first order, second order, etc.
Determines how the rate changes with concentration.
The time it takes for a reactant concentration to decrease by half.
A concept in chemical kinetics and nuclear chemistry.
Used to date fossils.
An equation that relates reaction rate to temperature.
Shows how rate increases with temperature.
Involves activation energy.
A value that expresses the ratio of products to reactants at equilibrium.
Can be $K_c$ or $K_p$.
A large value means more products are formed.
A principle that describes how a system at equilibrium responds to a change.
The system will shift to counteract the change.
A famous French chemist's principle.
A law that states the total enthalpy change for a reaction is the same.
Whether the reaction occurs in one step or in a series of steps.
Allows calculation of enthalpy change without direct measurement.
A process that occurs without the input of external energy.
A reaction that happens on its own.
Often a negative Gibbs free energy.
A thermodynamic potential that measures the useful work obtainable from a system.
A negative value means the reaction is spontaneous.
Symbol is $G$.
The splitting of a heavy atomic nucleus into two or more smaller nuclei.
Releases a large amount of energy.
Used in nuclear power plants.
The combining of two or more light atomic nuclei to form a heavier nucleus.
Releases an even larger amount of energy.
The process that powers the sun.
The process by which an unstable atomic nucleus loses energy by emitting radiation.
Discovered by Henri Becquerel.
Marie Curie studied this extensively.
Atoms of the same element with a different number of neutrons.
Have the same atomic number but different mass numbers.
Carbon-12 and Carbon-14 are examples.
An unstable isotope that decays and emits radiation.
Used in medicine and carbon dating.
A radioactive isotope.
The study of changes in the nucleus of an atom.
Includes topics like radioactivity and nuclear fission.
A branch of chemistry.
The emission of light as a result of a chemical reaction.
Glow sticks are a common example.
Light without heat.
The emission of light by a substance that has absorbed light or other electromagnetic radiation.
Light is emitted almost instantly.
The process in a blacklight poster.
The emission of light by a substance that has absorbed light or other electromagnetic radiation.
The light is emitted slowly over time.
Glow-in-the-dark stars are an example.
A large molecule made of repeating subunits.
Plastics are a common example.
Can be natural or synthetic.
A process of reacting monomers to form a polymer.
The creation of a large molecule from smaller ones.
How plastics are made.
A polymer that cannot be melted and reshaped.

Examples include epoxy resins and bakelite.

Can be recycled.
Examples include polyethylene and PVC.
The process of treating rubber with sulfur to improve its properties.
Makes rubber stronger and more durable.
Discovered by Charles Goodyear.
A metalloid element.
Found in sand and glass.
Used in semiconductors and computer chips.
An inorganic, nonmetallic solid.
Often hard and brittle.
Includes pottery, porcelain, and bricks.
The most common plastic.
Used to make plastic bags, bottles, and film.
A simple polymer.
A polymer with the acronym PVC.
Used to make pipes, flooring, and siding.
Known for its durability.
